articles.headline: In Spending Bill, Democrats Rely on Budget Gimmicks They Once Derided
articles.snippet: Budget experts say true cost of legislation could be $4 trillion as lawmakers rely on sleights of hand to bring down the price tag.
articles.abstract: Budget experts say true cost of legislation could be $4 trillion as lawmakers rely on sleights of hand to bring down the price tag.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At an impromptu news conference this week, Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, lamented the “shell games” and “budget gimmicks” he said his party was using to artificially reduce the $1.85 trillion price tag of the spending bill moving through Congress, saying the real cost was probably double that amount.

articles.headline: With Climate Pledges, Some Wall Street Titans Warn of Rising Prices
articles.snippet: Leaders of some of the world’s biggest financial firms say that the rush to transition to clean energy could have unintended consequences for the global economy.
articles.abstract: Leaders of some of the world’s biggest financial firms say that the rush to transition to clean energy could have unintended consequences for the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Big business finally seems to be taking the climate crisis seriously. After years spent lurking on the sidelines, the chief executives of the world’s largest banks, companies and investment firms this week took a spot at the center of the debate at COP26.

articles.headline: What Red Flags? Elizabeth Holmes Trial Exposes Investors’ Carelessness
articles.snippet: Start-up investors have often suspended skepticism while chasing a hot deal. The trial of Ms. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, has put that behavior under the spotlight.
articles.abstract: Start-up investors have often suspended skepticism while chasing a hot deal. The trial of Ms. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, has put that behavior under the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — In 2014, Dan Mosley, a lawyer and power broker among wealthy families, asked the entrepreneur Elizabeth Holmes for audited financial statements of Theranos, her blood testing start-up. Theranos never produced any, but Mr. Mosley invested $6 million in the company anyway — and wrote Ms. Holmes a gushing thank-you email for the opportunity.

articles.headline: California Tries to Close the Gap in Math, but Sets Off a Backlash
articles.snippet: Proposed guidelines in the state would de-emphasize calculus, reject the idea that some children are naturally gifted and build a connection to social justice. Critics say math shouldn’t be political.
articles.abstract: Proposed guidelines in the state would de-emphasize calculus, reject the idea that some children are naturally gifted and build a connection to social justice. Critics say math shouldn’t be political.
articles.lead_paragraph: If everything had gone according to plan, California would have approved new guidelines this month for math education in public schools.

articles.headline: A Nuclear-Powered Shower? Russia Tests a Climate Innovation.
articles.snippet: A remote Siberian town now has its own miniature nuclear plant as a Russian state company tests a new model for residential heating. Some see it as a tool to minimize climate change.
articles.abstract: A remote Siberian town now has its own miniature nuclear plant as a Russian state company tests a new model for residential heating. Some see it as a tool to minimize climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: To Build the Metaverse, Meta First Wants to Build Stores
articles.snippet: The social networking company has discussed opening physical stores to showcase its virtual reality and augmented reality devices.
articles.abstract: The social networking company has discussed opening physical stores to showcase its virtual reality and augmented reality devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Mark Zuckerberg’s first steps toward building the metaverse may be physical instead of virtual.

articles.headline: Wages are rising, but can they keep up with inflation?
articles.snippet: In the tug of war between wage growth and rising prices, it is not yet clear who is winning. It could matter for the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: In the tug of war between wage growth and rising prices, it is not yet clear who is winning. It could matter for the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: American workers are taking home bigger paychecks as employers pay up to attract and retain employees. But those same people are shelling out more for furniture, food and many other goods and services these days.

articles.headline: Job Gains Offer a Brighter Picture of the U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: Employers added 531,000 jobs in October, a big improvement from the previous month and a sign of optimism as the latest coronavirus surge eases.
articles.abstract: Employers added 531,000 jobs in October, a big improvement from the previous month and a sign of optimism as the latest coronavirus surge eases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy is showing renewed signs of life, with employers hiring workers in greater numbers than they have in months.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Talmon Joseph Smith

articles.headline: Pfizer Says Its Antiviral Pill Is Highly Effective in Treating Covid
articles.snippet: Pfizer’s is the second pill to show effectiveness against Covid-19, and it is the first purpose-built to attack the virus that causes the disease.
articles.abstract: Pfizer’s is the second pill to show effectiveness against Covid-19, and it is the first purpose-built to attack the virus that causes the disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer announced on Friday that its pill to treat Covid-19 had been found in a key clinical trial to be highly effective at preventing severe illness among at-risk people who received the drug soon after they exhibited symptoms, making it the second antiviral pill to demonstrate efficacy against Covid.

articles.headline: Crypto Is Cool. Now Get on the Yacht.
articles.snippet: NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future.
articles.abstract: NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The masters of the metaverse — thousands of CryptoPunks and Bored Apes, artists and hackers, starry-eyed idealists and profit-hungry speculators — descended on Manhattan this past week, looking for a glimpse of the future.

articles.headline: Near-Daily Covid Tests, Sleeping in Classrooms: Life in Covid-Zero China
articles.snippet: Residents in Ruili, in southwestern China, have been locked down four times in the past year as part of the country’s quest to eliminate the virus.
articles.abstract: Residents in Ruili, in southwestern China, have been locked down four times in the past year as part of the country’s quest to eliminate the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: The southwestern Chinese city of Ruili is small, remote and largely unknown internationally. It is also, when it comes to the coronavirus, perhaps the most tightly regulated place on earth.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
